Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Stabilization, Curation, Digitization and Data Management of the Wales, Alaska, Archaeology Project (1996-2006) Collections
Award.AbstractNarration:
The site of Wales, Alaska, on the coast of Bering Strait, exists at a crossroads of continents and provides a rich sequence of human activity for over 1200 years. Wales was the site of ten years of recent archaeological investigations, which produced approximately 30,000 artifacts, faunal and floral remains, and sediment samples. Artifacts include chipped and ground stone; carved antler, bone, and ivory objects; wooden implements; and pottery, much of which was recovered in excellent condition due to preservation by permafrost. These materials record over a millennium of human adaptation to an Arctic maritime environment, including the development of Indigenous whalingâ€”a process of critical importance to understanding the North American Arctic past.

This project will stabilize, curate, and digitize materials and documents produced by the Wales archaeological excavations between 1996 and 2006. All specimens will be cataloged and rehoused in archival-quality acid-free bags and boxes, ensuring they will be safely stored and accessible to scientists and descendant Inupiaq communities. Organic artifacts, currently in danger of degradation and irrevocable loss, will be evaluated and conserved. Artifacts and raw materials will be identified in the Inupiaq language and the terms will be incorporated into the collections database so that both Western scientific and Alaska Native designations are available to users. Selected artifacts will be photographed and scanned in 3D to enhance use of the collections. The entire Wales database will be made publicly available via a searchable web-based project-specific interface. Upon completion of project activities, artifacts, plant and animal remains, sediment samples and excavation documentation will be accessible for study, education, and heritage activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal for this NSF RAPID grant was to stabilize and curate collections of artifacts (nearly 30,000 artifacts, faunal lots, and bulk sediment samples), documentation, and data associated with Wales Archaeology Project (WAP). The WAP collected through NSF funding by Dr. Roger K. Harritt in Wales, Alaska, or traditionally referred to as Kingigan, between 1996 and 2006. Wales is an Iñupiaq community in northwestern Alaska. At the time of the grant’s award, it was urgent that we stabilize and curate this collection to reduce accelerated degradation occurring to objects, and to prevent any further irrevocable loss of contextual and research data. Prior to this RAPID project, the materials from the WAP were currently unusable by researchers and inaccessible to Alaska Native community members.

            As part of the project, we focused on making the collections and associated data easily accessible to researchers and descendant communities via improvements to our online Arctos collections database and through the creation of Wales collection specific website. The entire collection was cataloged with the majority of the accession’s records uploaded to the UAMN Arctos collections data management system (https://arctosdb.org). A collection specific website, Wales Archaeological Collections (https://nwoodx.com/wales/), was created to interface with Arctos and provides easier accessibility and search capabilities for Wales and Northern Alaskan communities, researchers, educators, and the public. Over 1700 objects have been photographed and will be accessible via Arctos and the Wales Archaeological Collections website.

            Our language component to work with traditional language and cultural experts to integrate Iñupiaq terms as cataloging categories into Arctos and the Wales collection website resulted in establishing a list of 100 terms for objects and 36 terms for materials. Audio files of these terms were incorporated into the database for users to hear their pronunciation. This exploratory aspect of this project has expanded to working with a larger group of Iñupiaq language and cultural experts that will improve the integration and elevation of traditional knowledge in the museum’s collections data and classificatory systems and within future research on the WAP collections and other collections from the Bering Straits region housed at UAMN.
